description: GIAC is a registered trademark of the Escal Institute of Advanced Technologies, Inc.  SANS is not affiliated with these courses. GIAC has been an industry leader in information security certifications for years. The GIAC Security Essentials (GSEC) is designed for Security Professionals who want to demonstrate that they are qualified for IT systems hands-on roles with respect to security tasks. GSEC is one of the DoD Approved 8570 Baseline Certifications for IAT Level II.
name: GIAC Security Essentials
subtitle: GSEC

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Mike explore the fundamentals of networking. They discuss the various network types such as local area networks, wide area networks, metropolitan area networks and personal area networks. They will also look at the different types of network topologies such as bus, ring, star, mesh and hybrid networks.
episodes.title: Networking Fundamentals
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.025 --> 00:00:08.549
Welcome to ITProTV, I'm your host,
Don Pezet. [CROSSTALK]

2
00:00:08.549 --> 00:00:11.700
>> You're watching ITProTV.

3
00:00:11.700 --> 00:00:14.620
>> Welcome to another exciting
episode here at ITProTV.

4
00:00:14.620 --> 00:00:15.880
I'm your host, Wes Bryan.

5
00:00:15.880 --> 00:00:21.972
And today, we are continuing through our
episode on GIA Security Fundamentals.

6
00:00:21.972 --> 00:00:22.745
Yeah, GIA, and

7
00:00:22.745 --> 00:00:26.620
I don't even know if I'm gonna get this
right ever through the whole entire thing.

8
00:00:26.620 --> 00:00:30.090
It's GSAC, and
that's the GIAC Security Fundamentals.

9
00:00:30.090 --> 00:00:33.140
And before I ruin that acronym anymore,
let's go ahead and

10
00:00:33.140 --> 00:00:34.260
bring Mike Roderick up here.

11
00:00:34.260 --> 00:00:35.260
Mike, how you doing, sir?

12
00:00:35.260 --> 00:00:36.550
>> Doing great, it is a mouthful.

13
00:00:36.550 --> 00:00:37.980
It's a lot to say.

14
00:00:37.980 --> 00:00:44.161
But this is the GIAC, the Global
Information Assurance Certification, GIAC.

15
00:00:44.161 --> 00:00:46.786
And then one of the certifications,

16
00:00:46.786 --> 00:00:52.390
that's basically the overall governing
body, if you will, the GIAC.

17
00:00:52.390 --> 00:00:55.850
And then they've created their
certifications, one of them being GSEC,

18
00:00:55.850 --> 00:01:00.200
or Security Essentials,
GIAC Security Essentials, or GSEC.

19
00:01:00.200 --> 00:01:01.930
That's what we're doing today.

20
00:01:01.930 --> 00:01:03.100
And in this particular one,

21
00:01:03.100 --> 00:01:06.710
where we're basically starting
with our network fundamentals.

22
00:01:06.710 --> 00:01:09.506
So we're gonna start at the beginning and
kinda work our way through.

23
00:01:09.506 --> 00:01:14.430
This is cuz of a different class and the
fact that we do a broad range of stuff.

24
00:01:14.430 --> 00:01:18.115
When we're studying for GSEC, we have
to be familiar with everything from

25
00:01:18.115 --> 00:01:20.930
the fundamentals up to some
of the more advanced topics.

26
00:01:20.930 --> 00:01:24.348
And so as we go through this, you might
think, wow, that's really simple,

27
00:01:24.348 --> 00:01:25.250
what class is this?

28
00:01:25.250 --> 00:01:27.020
Or that's really advanced.

29
00:01:27.020 --> 00:01:29.220
Keep in mind that this
kind of covers a lot,

30
00:01:29.220 --> 00:01:33.230
it's got a broad base of knowledge for
this exam, if you will.

31
00:01:33.230 --> 00:01:35.425
So, we're gonna start in the beginning,
and

32
00:01:35.425 --> 00:01:37.519
we're gonna do our network fundamentals.

33
00:01:37.519 --> 00:01:40.096
Some terminology that we
need to be familiar with and

34
00:01:40.096 --> 00:01:44.138
just some basic network and concepts that
without, you can't secure a network,

35
00:01:44.138 --> 00:01:45.677
you cannot secure your nodes.

36
00:01:45.677 --> 00:01:48.635
You can't secure your enterprise
if you don't understand

37
00:01:48.635 --> 00:01:50.180
the basic fundamentals of it.

38
00:01:50.180 --> 00:01:54.100
You can't communicate efficiently with
other people when you're talking about

39
00:01:54.100 --> 00:01:57.420
problems or issues or
ideas if you don't have that terminology.

40
00:01:57.420 --> 00:02:01.230
So always important to start with
that foundational knowledge,

41
00:02:01.230 --> 00:02:05.190
and we're gonna start with
basically network types, right?

42
00:02:05.190 --> 00:02:08.200
We need to be familiar when we’re talking
about our network, and somebody says,

43
00:02:08.200 --> 00:02:10.000
well, are you talking about your LAN?

44
00:02:10.000 --> 00:02:11.790
Or are you talking about your WAN?

45
00:02:11.790 --> 00:02:13.990
What the heck are they talking about?

46
00:02:13.990 --> 00:02:17.250
So those are some acronyms that I just
threw out at you, and let’s define them.

47
00:02:17.250 --> 00:02:21.782
We’re gonna start with LAN,
L-A-N, or local area network.

48
00:02:21.782 --> 00:02:25.089
And if we take a look at my screen here,
I’ve got a little drawing that kinda

49
00:02:25.089 --> 00:02:28.420
represents, or supposed to represent,
a local area network.

50
00:02:28.420 --> 00:02:32.140
And Wes, I know when I define a local area
network, it's basically everything that's

51
00:02:32.140 --> 00:02:36.290
in my little geographical region,
like my building here.

52
00:02:36.290 --> 00:02:39.900
And you can see in this drawing
I've got a router, some switches.

53
00:02:39.900 --> 00:02:41.752
I got a client subnet over here.

54
00:02:41.752 --> 00:02:46.380
I've got maybe a server backbone,
a wireless access point, wireless clients.

55
00:02:46.380 --> 00:02:48.750
But those are all here in this building.

56
00:02:48.750 --> 00:02:52.450
This building might be a single-floor,
it might be multiple floors.

57
00:02:52.450 --> 00:02:55.710
Right, but it's one geographic location.

58
00:02:55.710 --> 00:02:58.282
Right, and that's typically how I
define a local area network, right?

59
00:02:58.282 --> 00:02:59.760
>> Yeah, absolutely.

60
00:02:59.760 --> 00:03:05.020
I think about that geographic location in
a privately owned, self-contained network.

61
00:03:05.020 --> 00:03:07.009
And what I mean by that is both Mike and
I,

62
00:03:07.009 --> 00:03:09.190
well, we have our own local area networks.

63
00:03:09.190 --> 00:03:12.495
He's got one at his house, and I've been
on it before, whether he knows it or not.

64
00:03:12.495 --> 00:03:14.155
>> [LAUGH]
>> And I've got one at my house, but

65
00:03:14.155 --> 00:03:16.620
they're self contained, and
they are private entities.

66
00:03:16.620 --> 00:03:19.340
Which means he's gonna manage
his local area network,

67
00:03:19.340 --> 00:03:21.070
just like I'm gonna manage mine.

68
00:03:21.070 --> 00:03:22.715
It doesn't have to be a home
network either, right?

69
00:03:22.715 --> 00:03:24.390
This could also,
where we're going with this,

70
00:03:24.390 --> 00:03:26.810
is that this could also be in
a business environment as well.

71
00:03:26.810 --> 00:03:29.490
>> Absolutely, so
we've got our local area network,

72
00:03:29.490 --> 00:03:34.650
everything that's kinda, like you said,
under one management, all tied together.

73
00:03:34.650 --> 00:03:39.676
And the big key here is using LAN
protocols, which we haven't come to yet.

74
00:03:39.676 --> 00:03:41.520
We're gonna talk about
those in just a minute.

75
00:03:41.520 --> 00:03:46.438
But there's a set of protocols that
we'll use on our local area network.

76
00:03:46.438 --> 00:03:50.060
All right, now your local area network
can take some different forms, right?

77
00:03:50.060 --> 00:03:52.769
I've got this part back
here labeled intranet,

78
00:03:52.769 --> 00:03:55.160
you can see it's kinda behind a firewall.

79
00:03:55.160 --> 00:03:58.590
This is a very typical
small business environment,

80
00:03:58.590 --> 00:04:01.950
we've got a firewall protecting
yourself from the outside.

81
00:04:01.950 --> 00:04:05.360
Helping me control that traffic that's
coming into my local area network.

82
00:04:05.360 --> 00:04:07.570
Cuz we're attached to the outside world,
right?

83
00:04:07.570 --> 00:04:11.952
Very few networks are not attached to
the world wide web, to the Internet.

84
00:04:11.952 --> 00:04:15.060
So I can get out there and
gain access to other resources.

85
00:04:15.060 --> 00:04:18.040
But behind that firewall,
that's my local area network.

86
00:04:18.040 --> 00:04:22.020
Everything back there is under one
set of administrative control.

87
00:04:22.020 --> 00:04:24.960
Now your local area network
might include some other parts.

88
00:04:24.960 --> 00:04:29.620
You might have a second firewall
in between you and the Internet.

89
00:04:29.620 --> 00:04:33.650
And between those firewalls, there's
a little space, I've got two, right?

90
00:04:33.650 --> 00:04:35.901
I've got one back here, I've got one here,

91
00:04:35.901 --> 00:04:38.470
the Internet would be
out here to the right.

92
00:04:38.470 --> 00:04:41.588
So as traffic comes in,
it goes through this first firewall, and

93
00:04:41.588 --> 00:04:43.640
it kind of gets to this intermediate area.

94
00:04:43.640 --> 00:04:44.858
And then if allowed,

95
00:04:44.858 --> 00:04:49.230
it might go through that second
firewall back to my corporate network.

96
00:04:49.230 --> 00:04:51.660
And same thing for
traffic that's leaving my network.

97
00:04:51.660 --> 00:04:55.510
They're gonna go through that first
firewall, through this little area here,

98
00:04:55.510 --> 00:04:58.480
and out through that second
firewall to the Internet.

99
00:04:58.480 --> 00:04:59.190
>> And Mike,

100
00:04:59.190 --> 00:05:02.060
help me out here because you already
helped us with the one acronym there.

101
00:05:02.060 --> 00:05:04.460
I see LAN, and
it is defined as local area network.

102
00:05:04.460 --> 00:05:08.230
I also see three sets of letters
up there as well called a DMZ.

103
00:05:08.230 --> 00:05:09.340
You wanna help me out with that one?

104
00:05:09.340 --> 00:05:11.787
>> I have no idea, I just type those out.

105
00:05:11.787 --> 00:05:16.590
No, a DMZ is the name I'm gonna give
that area between those two firewalls.

106
00:05:16.590 --> 00:05:18.910
It's known as a demilitarized zone.

107
00:05:18.910 --> 00:05:20.910
It has other names,
depending on who you're talking to or

108
00:05:20.910 --> 00:05:22.240
what book you're reading.

109
00:05:22.240 --> 00:05:26.270
You might see it referenced as
a screened subnet, right, so

110
00:05:26.270 --> 00:05:28.600
a subnet between those two firewalls.

111
00:05:28.600 --> 00:05:31.900
You also might see it referenced
as a perimeter network,

112
00:05:31.900 --> 00:05:34.790
because it is on the perimeter
of your network.

113
00:05:34.790 --> 00:05:39.000
And just like a demilitarized zone
in the physical world, right,

114
00:05:39.000 --> 00:05:41.380
it's like a buffer space there.

115
00:05:41.380 --> 00:05:45.430
This is an area of my network that I'm
gonna allow certain things to happen

116
00:05:45.430 --> 00:05:50.620
that I would not allow on my Internet,
back here behind this second firewall.

117
00:05:50.620 --> 00:05:53.330
For example, I've got a website.

118
00:05:53.330 --> 00:05:57.250
People come to my website to buy
my product, so I can make money.

119
00:05:57.250 --> 00:06:01.160
So I need to allow public,
anonymous access to that website.

120
00:06:01.160 --> 00:06:04.130
Well, I can't allow
public anonymous access

121
00:06:04.130 --> 00:06:07.330
to my internal network on
my corporate LAN, right?

122
00:06:07.330 --> 00:06:09.100
So there,
you start to see some of the differences.

123
00:06:09.100 --> 00:06:13.660
On this front firewall, it's not
gonna be configured quite as strict.

124
00:06:13.660 --> 00:06:15.510
It's gonna allow certain things through,

125
00:06:15.510 --> 00:06:19.430
like that public anonymous
access to that web front-end.

126
00:06:19.430 --> 00:06:22.890
This back firewall is gonna be
configured a lot more stringent.

127
00:06:22.890 --> 00:06:25.140
It's not gonna allow that
kind of thing through.

128
00:06:25.140 --> 00:06:30.330
Only certain machines or certain traffic
is gonna be allowed to actually penetrate

129
00:06:30.330 --> 00:06:35.600
into the corporate network back here,
that private part, my intranet.

130
00:06:35.600 --> 00:06:38.960
So whatever you call it, DMZ,
screened subnet, perimeter network,

131
00:06:38.960 --> 00:06:42.320
it acts as a little bit of buffer
between you and the outside world.

132
00:06:42.320 --> 00:06:47.100
It's also where we put our
resources that need public access.

133
00:06:47.100 --> 00:06:51.530
Or another one you might see is
what's called an extranet, right?

134
00:06:51.530 --> 00:06:54.280
Very similar to what I've
got drawn here with the DMZ.

135
00:06:54.280 --> 00:06:56.770
I might have a partner organization.

136
00:06:56.770 --> 00:07:00.340
And maybe I'm a supplier of raw materials,
and

137
00:07:00.340 --> 00:07:03.350
they're a manufacturer and
they need to purchase this stuff.

138
00:07:03.350 --> 00:07:08.630
And so I set up an area of my network
where their employees can come in and

139
00:07:08.630 --> 00:07:12.880
see how much raw materials we have,
place orders, and look at ship dates and

140
00:07:12.880 --> 00:07:14.182
things like that.

141
00:07:14.182 --> 00:07:18.930
I wanna provide that to them, but I don't
want that company's employees coming into

142
00:07:18.930 --> 00:07:23.950
my local area network back into
my intranet, don't need that.

143
00:07:23.950 --> 00:07:28.960
So I make it part of my network,
not quite publicly available.

144
00:07:28.960 --> 00:07:33.920
It's like the screen subnet or a DMZ
might be available to anonymous access.

145
00:07:33.920 --> 00:07:38.560
My extranet is only available
to Company XYZ from the outside.

146
00:07:38.560 --> 00:07:41.880
Or I probably have several
people that I sell to.

147
00:07:41.880 --> 00:07:46.530
So my entire list of companies
that I provide raw materials to,

148
00:07:46.530 --> 00:07:48.820
they might have access to my extranet.

149
00:07:48.820 --> 00:07:51.321
The public's not allowed
into the extranet, right?

150
00:07:51.321 --> 00:07:56.471
So it's a part of my network that I can
make available to the outside basically.

151
00:07:56.471 --> 00:07:59.996
>> Mike, now that local area network that
you've got in your diagram there, or

152
00:07:59.996 --> 00:08:03.865
the intranet as you've been talking about,
I notice you got a few devices in there.

153
00:08:03.865 --> 00:08:08.441
And does it matter whether I'm
a A small home environment.

154
00:08:08.441 --> 00:08:11.440
We're not talking business here or
a corporate environment.

155
00:08:11.440 --> 00:08:12.980
LAN generally is not restricted,

156
00:08:12.980 --> 00:08:16.040
or is it, to the amount of
devices you have on that network.

157
00:08:16.040 --> 00:08:16.800
>> It's not.

158
00:08:16.800 --> 00:08:21.010
It can be just a single node
back there with no firewall.

159
00:08:21.010 --> 00:08:24.960
Maybe you've got a router that you
picked up from your cable provider or

160
00:08:24.960 --> 00:08:28.940
your Internet service provider and
then you plug straight into that.

161
00:08:28.940 --> 00:08:29.780
Hopefully not.

162
00:08:29.780 --> 00:08:31.690
Hopefully you know better than that.

163
00:08:31.690 --> 00:08:35.690
But then you've got at least some kind of
router and or switch sitting back there.

164
00:08:35.690 --> 00:08:39.170
But absolutely,
a single node would still be an intranet.

165
00:08:39.170 --> 00:08:43.410
It would still be using LAN-based
protocols to communicate with, well,

166
00:08:43.410 --> 00:08:44.060
nobody else.

167
00:08:44.060 --> 00:08:45.740
But let's say you added a second node,
right?

168
00:08:45.740 --> 00:08:48.480
And now your LAN is
a little more functional.

169
00:08:48.480 --> 00:08:51.000
But even with a single node you
would still be considered a LAN.

170
00:08:51.000 --> 00:08:55.800
So it's really all about the fact that
it's under my administrative control and

171
00:08:55.800 --> 00:09:00.730
that it's geographically in one spot,
I guess.

172
00:09:00.730 --> 00:09:03.750
>> So if I'm watching this for the very
first time, I don't have to worry about

173
00:09:03.750 --> 00:09:08.260
being confused if this is a LAN because
it has XYZ devices versus this is

174
00:09:08.260 --> 00:09:11.210
a LAN because it's got three floors and
it's a corporate owned entity.

175
00:09:11.210 --> 00:09:13.610
It's just like you said,
geographical location and

176
00:09:13.610 --> 00:09:17.090
just being under the administrative
control of or whoever runs the network.

177
00:09:17.090 --> 00:09:18.520
>> Exactly right.

178
00:09:18.520 --> 00:09:23.210
All right so now let's take a step up
from LAN and we're gonna go to WAN.

179
00:09:23.210 --> 00:09:26.420
So LAN was local area network.

180
00:09:26.420 --> 00:09:29.850
We talk about a WAN,
we're talking about a wide area network.

181
00:09:29.850 --> 00:09:33.340
And the names, if you start to pick up
on the names kind of gives you a hint,

182
00:09:33.340 --> 00:09:35.210
right, wide area.

183
00:09:35.210 --> 00:09:40.280
That tells me it's probably gonna be
a little more geographically dispersed.

184
00:09:40.280 --> 00:09:44.410
And so what I've got on my screen
now is our business has grown.

185
00:09:44.410 --> 00:09:46.480
We've got an office in New York.

186
00:09:46.480 --> 00:09:48.010
We've got another office in London.

187
00:09:48.010 --> 00:09:50.560
And we've got another office in Sydney.

188
00:09:50.560 --> 00:09:56.310
Now what you'll notice, or should notice
here I can get my mouse to play along.

189
00:09:56.310 --> 00:09:59.400
Is, let's take just this New York for
a second.

190
00:09:59.400 --> 00:10:03.900
Notice it looks very similar, right,
to what we were just looking at for a LAN?

191
00:10:03.900 --> 00:10:06.310
Because I've basically copied and
paste my drawing.

192
00:10:06.310 --> 00:10:11.310
Because it is, New York is a LAN,
that is a local area network there.

193
00:10:11.310 --> 00:10:14.540
But my organization has three of those.

194
00:10:14.540 --> 00:10:18.440
Has one over here in London and
another one in Sydney.

195
00:10:18.440 --> 00:10:19.300
And I apologize.

196
00:10:19.300 --> 00:10:21.110
I hope I'm not making you sick there.

197
00:10:21.110 --> 00:10:23.360
We'll stop with the zooming around.

198
00:10:23.360 --> 00:10:26.220
So I've got basically
three local area networks.

199
00:10:26.220 --> 00:10:28.670
One in London, one in New York,
And one in Sydney.

200
00:10:29.740 --> 00:10:33.360
Now I need to tie these guys together,
because people in London need to access

201
00:10:33.360 --> 00:10:36.620
resources in New York and
Sydney and vise versa.

202
00:10:36.620 --> 00:10:38.630
So when we start bringing
these office together,

203
00:10:38.630 --> 00:10:44.230
start connecting them, now we're talking
about our wide area network, all right?

204
00:10:44.230 --> 00:10:48.185
Wide area networks or
WANs travel across or

205
00:10:48.185 --> 00:10:54.160
designed to connect geographically
dispersed locations, all right.

206
00:10:54.160 --> 00:10:58.160
They do use a different set of protocols
which will come too here in just a minute.

207
00:10:58.160 --> 00:11:00.448
I wanna make sure we get
the concept down first.

208
00:11:00.448 --> 00:11:04.260
So wide area network is really
nothing more than an collection of

209
00:11:04.260 --> 00:11:08.970
local area networks kinda connected
together cuz we have enterprise admins.

210
00:11:08.970 --> 00:11:10.630
So New York is under my control.

211
00:11:10.630 --> 00:11:12.460
London is also under my control.

212
00:11:12.460 --> 00:11:14.410
Sydney is also under my control.

213
00:11:14.410 --> 00:11:17.500
And by our definition of LAN,
we said if it was a network under a single

214
00:11:17.500 --> 00:11:19.010
administrative control,
it should be a LAN.

215
00:11:19.010 --> 00:11:22.750
It was the second part of that LAN
definition that's getting us, right?

216
00:11:22.750 --> 00:11:25.740
It's not in a geographic or
single geographic location.

217
00:11:25.740 --> 00:11:27.920
Now we're talking about
three different locations.

218
00:11:27.920 --> 00:11:32.610
So still under one administrative control
but now I'm geographically dispersed.

219
00:11:32.610 --> 00:11:35.160
Now were talking about
the wide area network.

220
00:11:35.160 --> 00:11:38.964

It's basically scrambling the data and

450
00:23:15.713 --> 00:23:18.861
I'm not going to be able to make
sense out of what's going on.

451
00:23:18.861 --> 00:23:23.810
I'll lose that, what's a good word for
it, you just can't interpret it.

452
00:23:23.810 --> 00:23:25.630
So you can't read the data.

453
00:23:25.630 --> 00:23:27.620
So basically nobody can communicate again.

454
00:23:27.620 --> 00:23:30.890
>> You know I make the joke here that
you're probably only going to see them in

455
00:23:30.890 --> 00:23:34.318
a museum, but I was watching some of
the earlier days when this was the network

456
00:23:34.318 --> 00:23:35.819
technology on some kind of show.

457
00:23:35.819 --> 00:23:39.786
And one of the earlier inventors,
inventors of this product said, you can

458
00:23:39.786 --> 00:23:43.421
always tell when somebody wanted a break
cuz all they have to do is reach down and

459
00:23:43.421 --> 00:23:45.484
pull one of those
terminators off the line.

460
00:23:45.484 --> 00:23:49.389
And then everybody's faces would slowly
come up from their cubes wondering why's

461
00:23:49.389 --> 00:23:50.310
the network down.

462
00:23:50.310 --> 00:23:53.993
So I can see this would be a fun time at
the office when this network didn't work.

463
00:23:53.993 --> 00:23:55.232
>> And the scary thing was Wes,

464
00:23:55.232 --> 00:23:57.977
what if I broke this cable here
does that bother my network too?

465
00:23:57.977 --> 00:23:59.926
>> It brings the whole network
to still a single cable.

466
00:23:59.926 --> 00:24:02.292
>> That's right cuz this
whole thing you can imagine,

467
00:24:02.292 --> 00:24:04.622
is the signal going out
across all of these cables.

468
00:24:04.622 --> 00:24:07.931
So It's not just a break in the main line.

469
00:24:07.931 --> 00:24:12.248
If Wes wanted that break, [LAUGH]
literally, and breaks the cable there,

470
00:24:12.248 --> 00:24:13.860
yeah, everybody is down.

471
00:24:13.860 --> 00:24:18.070
So buses had their place in history.

472
00:24:18.070 --> 00:24:20.180
You don't see them that often anymore.

473
00:24:20.180 --> 00:24:24.820
Let's move onto a little more modern
layout, a little modern topology.

474
00:24:24.820 --> 00:24:26.990
And that's gonna be our star.

475
00:24:26.990 --> 00:24:27.920
And you can see,

476
00:24:27.920 --> 00:24:32.990
it gets the name from the pattern that it
makes when we kinda draw it out like this.

477
00:24:32.990 --> 00:24:34.640
But the big difference between a bus and

478
00:24:34.640 --> 00:24:39.180
a star is I now have a central
connectivity device.

479
00:24:39.180 --> 00:24:42.430
I have something tying all
of these things together.

480
00:24:42.430 --> 00:24:44.650
So instead of there
being that backbone and

481
00:24:44.650 --> 00:24:48.690
everybody T-ing into
this backbone down here.

482
00:24:48.690 --> 00:24:53.392
We've got this one device in the middle,
and everything plugs into that one device.

483
00:24:53.392 --> 00:24:56.287
And this is what we would
call a star topology.

484
00:24:56.287 --> 00:24:59.047
Now that device in
the middle could be a hub,

485
00:24:59.047 --> 00:25:01.965
could be a switch,
could be a bridge, right?

486
00:25:01.965 --> 00:25:05.170
We'll talk about these
devices as we go along.

487
00:25:05.170 --> 00:25:09.540
Advantages to this layout, well, is
going to be the fact that, what happens,

488
00:25:09.540 --> 00:25:11.440
Wes, if this cable breaks here?

489
00:25:11.440 --> 00:25:14.340
>> Well, with a connectivity device,
I think it isolates just that one

490
00:25:14.340 --> 00:25:17.330
node that's connected to the device
from the rest of the network.

491
00:25:17.330 --> 00:25:18.360
>> That's exactly right.

492
00:25:18.360 --> 00:25:20.250
So that one node would be down.

493
00:25:20.250 --> 00:25:22.180
Nobody could communicate with this node.

494
00:25:22.180 --> 00:25:25.060
This node could communicate with
nobody else, but that's it.

495
00:25:25.060 --> 00:25:28.440
The other three nodes on this network
are still communicating just fine.

496
00:25:28.440 --> 00:25:32.260
So it ends up creating this point-to-point
connection between the node and

497
00:25:32.260 --> 00:25:34.070
that central connectivity device.

498
00:25:34.070 --> 00:25:37.240
Which eliminates my need for
one, for terminators.

499
00:25:37.240 --> 00:25:41.910
And two, the single cable break
brings down the entire network.

500
00:25:41.910 --> 00:25:42.610
Flexibility.

501
00:25:42.610 --> 00:25:46.350
When I need to plug in a new node, as long
as there's an extra port on this guy,

502
00:25:46.350 --> 00:25:48.180
I can just pop a new node out here.

503
00:25:48.180 --> 00:25:51.180
And connect it up, and
we're good to go, all right?

504
00:25:51.180 --> 00:25:56.428
Downside is to connect that node,
I had to make a home run.

505
00:25:56.428 --> 00:25:58.850
And I'm not talking about hitting
it out of the park, right?

506
00:25:58.850 --> 00:26:03.200
I've gotta run a wire from that person's
office, that new computer he just got,

507
00:26:03.200 --> 00:26:04.820
up the wall, over the attic, down in.

508
00:26:04.820 --> 00:26:07.410
Wherever that central
connectivity device is,

509
00:26:07.410 --> 00:26:10.310
I've gotta connect that
machine to it somehow, right?

510
00:26:10.310 --> 00:26:15.950
So a lot more cable involved when we
deal with setting up star topologies.

511
00:26:15.950 --> 00:26:19.009
>> Now it's interesting, and
I think you did this on purpose here.

512
00:26:19.009 --> 00:26:21.100
>> [LAUGH]
>> Now you showed us the first one which

513
00:26:21.100 --> 00:26:24.179
was probably one that we will
never really see anymore.

514
00:26:24.179 --> 00:26:25.690
Because it's just not utilize anymore.

515
00:26:25.690 --> 00:26:27.587
Now this almost is the polar reverse.

516
00:26:27.587 --> 00:26:30.733
How common is this type of
network in today's day and age?

517
00:26:30.733 --> 00:26:32.010
>> This is just about everywhere.

518
00:26:32.010 --> 00:26:34.862
Just about every network you
run into is gonna be switched,

519
00:26:34.862 --> 00:26:36.905
what they call switched Ethernet.

520
00:26:36.905 --> 00:26:41.369
Meaning that we're running star topologies
with a central connectivity device.

521
00:26:41.369 --> 00:26:42.885
Almost always a switch.

522
00:26:42.885 --> 00:26:46.455
Hubs, which we're gonna talk about later,
you rarely see those anymore.

523
00:26:46.455 --> 00:26:49.970
Bridges you really don't see
those much anymore except for

524
00:26:49.970 --> 00:26:51.802
in special needs situations.

525
00:26:51.802 --> 00:26:56.752
But to Wes's point, yeah, just about every
single network is gonna be laid out in

526
00:26:56.752 --> 00:27:00.000
a star using a central
connectivity device.

527
00:27:00.000 --> 00:27:02.760
Well, Mike,
I know we got a lot more to go.

528
00:27:02.760 --> 00:27:06.610
You guys out there that are sharp probably
seen that we've got a lot more of those

529
00:27:06.610 --> 00:27:07.580
diagrams there.

530
00:27:07.580 --> 00:27:08.760
You can see all the little tabs.

531
00:27:08.760 --> 00:27:11.750
But I'll tell you what we
don't have time for right now.

532
00:27:11.750 --> 00:27:12.920
And that's the time on that clock.

533
00:27:12.920 --> 00:27:15.567
So Mike, were you gonna go ahead and
wrap this up?

534
00:27:15.567 --> 00:27:16.670
And come back in a part two, and

535
00:27:16.670 --> 00:27:18.650
we'll continue along in
our network fundamentals?

536
00:27:18.650 --> 00:27:19.570
>> Sounds like a plan.

537
00:27:19.570 --> 00:27:22.170
>> All right, very good, well,
that's a perfect place to stop.

538
00:27:22.170 --> 00:27:23.320
Thank you, Mike, for being here.

539
00:27:23.320 --> 00:27:25.832
We'll see you guys, hopefully,
see you in the next episode.

540
00:27:25.832 --> 00:27:28.895
Signing out for ITProTV,
I have been your host, Wes Bryan.

541
00:27:28.895 --> 00:27:29.590
>> And I'm Mike Rodrick.

542
00:27:29.590 --> 00:27:30.908
>> And we'll see you next time.

543
00:27:30.908 --> 00:27:37.993
[MUSIC]

544
00:27:37.993 --> 00:27:41.195
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Mike continue their exploration of network fundamentals. They continue with network topologies then move into network devices such as hubs, bridges, routers and switches.
episodes.title: Networking Fundamentals Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Mike continue their journey through networking fundamentals. They discuss IP addressing basics like decimal and binary notation as well as hexadecimal notation. They will also look at converting between the different notations.
episodes.title: Networking Fundamentals Part 3

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Mike continue their journey through networking fundamentals. They continue with IP address basics such as subnet masks as well as public and private IP addresses.
episodes.title: Networking Fundamentals Part 4

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Mike continue their journey through networking fundamentals. They continue with IP address basics such as subnetting as well as introducing IPv6 the next generation addressing protocol.
episodes.title: Networking Fundamentals Part 5

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Mike continue their exploration of network fundamentals. They continue their look into IPv6 the next generation addressing protocol
episodes.title: Networking Fundamentals Part 6

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Mike dive into one of the most important services in networking known as the domain naming system or DNS. They look at the architecture, service, records as well as explaining the process of name resolution within networks today.
episodes.title: Understanding DNS

episodes.description: In this episode Wes and Mike dive into the world of protocols and packets. They take a look at the basic structure of protocol as well as looking at TCP and UDP header formats. They cover some of the basics of the Open Systems Interconnection (OSI) model as well as the TCP/IP protocol stack.
episodes.title: Protocols and Packets

episodes.description: In this episode Wes and Mike continue their exploration into the world of protocols and packets. They continue a looking at the basic structure of TCP and UDP header formats, as well as looking and the ICMP header. They will also demonstrate capturing TCP/IP packets on a network and how to interpret the data. They will introduce TCP/IP sockets, ports and port ranges.
episodes.title: Protocols and Packets Part 2

episodes.description: In this show, Mike and Cherokee begin disusing network perimeter security by describing the functions of different types of firewalls. They also discuss where and how to implement a firewall. Lastly, they explain the role of a proxy.
episodes.title: Network Security

episodes.description: In this show, Cherokee and Mike begin discussing  Virtual Private Networks (VPNs). Mike explains why and how they may be utilized. They also discuss the associated tunneling and encryption protocols. Several other topics such as web application security, active content, attacks, defenses, wireless security and misconceptions.
episodes.title: Network Security Part 2

episodes.description: Mike and Cherokee discuss vulnerability scanning  in this show. They begin by examining different approaches and remediation methods. Mike gives a couple of demonstrations including Nessus and Nmap.
episodes.title: Vulnerability Scanning

episodes.description: In this episode, Cherokee and Mike compare and contrast Intrusion Detection and Prevention systems (IDSs and IPSs). They not only share the pros and cons  of each, they also discuss how to logically place them within a network to suite your needs.
episodes.title: IDS and IPS

episodes.description: Cherokee and Mike continue the previous discussion focusing on IPSs and IDSs. First, Mike shows us some examples of these systems followed by a demonstration of Snort. They round out the conversation explaining the purpose of honeypots and honeynets.
episodes.title: IDS and IPS Part 2

episodes.description: Cherokee and Mike begin this discussion by explaining authentication and password management. They explain the difference between the AAAs (authentication, authorization, and accountability. They also discuss the CIA (confidentiality, integrity, and availability) as well as a couple of access control methods.
episodes.title: Access Control

episodes.description: In this episode Mike and Cherokee talk about different methods one may use to crack a password. They first explain the difference between a dictionary, brute force and hybrid attack. Next, Mike demonstrates how to use Cain and Abel to crack a password.
episodes.title: Access Control Part 2

episodes.description: In this show Mike and Cherokee discuss authentication methods such as multi-factor using bio-metrics or tokens. Mike then shows a list of security recommendations published by the Center for Internet Security. Lastly, they talk about Security  Information and Event Management systems (SIEM).
episodes.title: Access Control Part 3

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike continue their discussion on Risk Management, jumping back in by explaining both qualitative and quantitative risk assessment methodologies. They also show you common methods for calculating risk and approaches for dealing with risk (transfer, accept, avoid, or mitigate).
episodes.title: Risk Management

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike continue their discussion on Risk Management, jumping back in by explaining both qualitative and quantitative risk assessment methodologies. They also show you common methods for calculating risk and approaches for dealing with risk (transfer, accept, avoid, or mitigate).
episodes.title: Risk Management Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike take the time to explore common malware types and attacks. They start by looking at attack methods like phishing, SQL injection, cross-site scripting(XSS), and Denial of Service(DoS). Then they look into network mapping/scanning techniques and defining viruses/malicious code.
episodes.title: Attacks and Malware

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike return to their conversation about common network attacks and malware. They pick back up by exploring more malicious programs like Trojan Horses, spyware, and rootkits. They also describe the types of Information Warfare, including Advanced Persistent Threats(APT), Asymmetric Warfare, and offensive defense.
episodes.title: Attacks and Malware Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike explore the fundamentals of Incident Handling. They begin by explaining how to prepare for an incident through policies and training. Then they tackle incident identification, containment, eradication, and recovery. They finish by exploring investigation techniques and legal considerations.
episodes.title: Incident Response

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Mike explore the concepts of cryptography fundamentals. They look at a encryption in it’s basic form as well as discussing a couple different cipher types like transposition and substitution ciphers. They explain the difference between Caesar and Vigenere ciphers and talk about mono-alphabetic and poly-alphabetic ciphers.
episodes.title: Cryptography Fundamentals

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Mike continue their exploration of the concepts of cryptography fundamentals. They look stream ciphers and block ciphers as well as the benefits and drawbacks of both. They will also examine different algorithms such as symmetric, asymmetric encryption and hashing.
episodes.title: Cryptography Fundamentals Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Mike tackle the world of public key infrastructure (PKI) and dive more into asymmetric key encryption, the infrastructure, and components such as certificates, certificate issuance, certificate validation, smart cards and certificate-based authentication. They will also look at certificate authorities (CAs), root CAs and the hierarchical infrastructure.
episodes.title: PKI and Steganography

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Mike continue their exploration of public key infrastructure (PKI) with a demonstration on certificates on SSL-Based websites as well as discussing purchasing a certificates through external certificate authorities. They look at Active Directory Certificate Services inside of Windows Server as well as talking about certificate maintenance.
episodes.title: PKI and Steganography Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Mike continue their exploration of public key infrastructure (PKI) and a cryptographic process called steganography. They look at the basics of cryptographic attacks such as ciphertext-only, known plaintext, chosen plaintext and chosen ciphertext attacks. They will also talk about cryptanalysis concepts like differential, linear, side channels  cryptanalysis and more. Finally, they will introduce the basics in a cryptographic technique called steganography.
episodes.title: PKI and Steganography Part 3

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Mike explain Microsoft Windows workgroups and Active Directory domains. They look at the decentralized nature of Windows workgroups and compare that to the centralized environment of Active Directory domains. They explore the authentication mechanisms used to log users on in workgroups and domains.
episodes.title: Workgroups and Domains

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Mike demonstrate controlling access to resource within a Windows environment through permissions. They look at NTFS and shared permissions as well as discussing the two permission set’s interaction with each other. They will also look at printer permissions that can be applied to shared printers within a network.
episodes.title: Windows Permissions

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Mike continue their demonstration on controlling access to resource within a Windows environment through permissions. They look at protecting access to the Windows Registry by setting permissions as well as looking at permission in Active Directory. They talk about Active Directory permission delegation and domain security through Kerberos and smart cards.
episodes.title: Windows Permissions Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Mike discuss concepts related to patch management of Windows-based systems through updates. They dive into the different components of updates such as service packs, hot fixes, automatic updates and the Windows Server Update Service also known as WSUS.
episodes.title: Windows Updates

episodes.description: In this episode Wes and Mike look at the various concepts surrounding maintaining Windows systems . They explain the overall backup process as well as demonstrate that process through the Windows Server Backup tool. They explore the importance of system state information and backup types.
episodes.title: Windows Backup and Restore

episodes.description: In this episode Wes and Mike continue their discussion on various concepts surrounding maintaining Windows systems . They explain the restore process as well as demonstrate the restoration process through the Windows Server Backup tool. They also will look at driver rollback and Windows Update basics.
episodes.title: Windows Backup and Restore Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode Wes and Mike discuss the importance and utilization of Security Templates in a Windows environment as well as controlling settings through Group Policy in Windows domains. They explore password policies, lockout policies, software restriction policies and AppLocker.
episodes.title: Templates and Group Policy

episodes.description: In this episode Wes and Mike continue their discussion on security templates in a Windows environment as well as controlling settings through Group Policy in Windows domains. They focus on the Group Policy side of the Windows environment. They explore password policies, lockout policies, software restriction policies and AppLocker.
episodes.title: Templates and Group Policy Part 2

episodes.description: In this show Cherokee and Mike begin explaining Windows security starting with Microsoft Firewall. Watch Mike demonstrate how to create and implement custom rules.
episodes.title: Windows Network Security

episodes.description: This is a continuation where Cherokee and Mike speak on IPSec. Mike demonstrates how to create IPSec policies in a Windows environment.
episodes.title: Windows Network Security Part 2

episodes.description: Learn the difference between several types of counts as Mike and Cherokee cover them individually. Mike explains Built-in Local System Accounts, Built-in Local Service Accounts, Built-in Network Services Accounts and Created Service Accounts. Lastly, they discuss some common best practices to follow.
episodes.title: Windows Network Security Part 3

episodes.description: Never worked with Linux before? Have no fear Daniel and Cherokee take you back to the basics. This episode provides a good foundation and breakdown of the different Linux distributions, where they originated and what they are used for.
episodes.title: Linux Overview

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike continue to cover some Linux foundational knowledge. In particular, they focus on TCP/IP configuration. They demonstrate how to configure a Linux system as a DHCP client as well as how to statically map an IP address, subnet mask, default gateway and DNS server.
episodes.title: Linux Overview Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike continue to cover some Linux foundational knowledge. This time they focus on processes and the tools we can use to work with them. They start with TOP, as well as PS commands. Then they demonstrate examining background processes using Jobs, and how to kill a process.
episodes.title: Linux Overview Part 3

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike begin their exploration into configuring a Linux system, particularly in a multi-user environment. They look at creating a non-administrative account that can be used for everyday computing, and how to escalate privileges when necessary. They also demonstrate creating additional users and controlling their access.
episodes.title: Linux Configuration Fundamentals

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Don continue the explorations of the basics of Linux configurations. They talk about setting password controls, including the pluggable authentication module or PAM and extending the capabilities by the installation of additional modules. They also look at basic strong password configurations and checking password through cracklib and pwquality.
episodes.title: Linux Configuration Fundamentals Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Don continue the explorations of the basics of Linux configurations. They look at permissions, the available permissions, numeric vs. symbolic permission representation, setting sticky bits, GUIDs, SUIDs, patching, updates and backups.
episodes.title: Linux Configuration Fundamentals Part 3

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike explore Virtualization as it pertains to maintaining a secure environment. They give you a good overview of what makes up a virtual environment as well as common concepts like Type1 vs Type2 hypervisors, use cases, and security procedures like hardening, auditing, and management systems.
episodes.title: Virtualization
